review.title: Learning Fuzzy {\beta}-Certain and {\beta}-Possible rules from incomplete quantitative data by rough sets
review.abstract: The rough-set theory proposed by Pawlak, has been widely used in dealing with data classification problems. The original rough-set model is, however, quite sensitive to noisy data. Tzung thus proposed deals with the problem of producing a set of fuzzy certain and fuzzy possible rules from quantitative data with a predefined tolerance degree of uncertainty and misclassification. This model allowed, which combines the variable precision rough-set model and the fuzzy set theory, is thus proposed to solve this problem. This paper thus deals with the problem of producing a set of fuzzy certain and fuzzy possible rules from incomplete quantitative data with a predefined tolerance degree of uncertainty and misclassification. A new method, incomplete quantitative data for rough-set model and the fuzzy set theory, is thus proposed to solve this problem. It first transforms each quantitative value into a fuzzy set of linguistic terms using membership functions and then finding incomplete quantitative data with lower and the fuzzy upper approximations. It second calculates the fuzzy {\beta}-lower and the fuzzy {\beta}-upper approximations. The certain and possible rules are then generated based on these fuzzy approximations. These rules can then be used to classify unknown objects.

metadata.title: Mining Fuzzy β-Certain and β-Possible rules from incomplete quantitative data by rough sets

sections.text: Keywords Component: Fuzzy set; Rough set; Data mining; Certain rules; β rule; Quantitative values; Incomplete DataI β ². IntroductionMachine Learning and Data Mining techniques have recently been developed to implicitly find meaningful patterns and ease the knowledge-acquisition bottleneck. Among these approaches, deriving conclusions or association rules from educational examples is the most common [9,12,13]. Faced with a number of examples and counter-examples of a concept, the learning program attempts to induce general rules that describe all or most positive educational instances and none or few of the counter-examples [6,7]. If the educational instances belong to more than two classes, the learning program will induce general rules that describe each class. Recently, the coarse theory has been used in argumentation and knowledge acquisition for expert systems [4,14]. It was proposed by Pawlak in 1982, using the concept of equivalence classes as a basic principle.

[6,17] mentioned that the main issue in the rough-set approach was the formation of good rules.
The rough-set theory, proposed by Pawlak in 1982, can serve as a new mathematical tool to deal with data classification problems [19].
The original rough-set model is quite sensitive to noisy data [7].
In the past, several methods were proposed to handle the problem of incomplete data sets [21].
Incomplete data sets may also be directly processed in a particular way to get the rules [20,22].
Incomplete data sets may also be directly processed in a particular way to get the rules [20,22].
In the [20] proposed a rough-set approach to directly learn rules from incomplete data sets without guessing unknown attribute values.
In the [22] modified [20] approach by introducing the rough entropy to distinguish the power of the attribute subsets that have the same partition for similarity relations.
